headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 8:15PM CDT by NWS Kansas City/Pleasant Hill MO
description:
At 814 PM CDT, emergency management reported a strong thunderstorm
near Albany, moving northeast at 40 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and penny size hail.

SOURCE...Emergency management.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is
possible.

Locations impacted include...
Bethany, Albany, New Hampton, and Martinsville.

This includes Interstate 35 in Missouri between mile markers 92 and
101.
areaDesc: Gentry; Harrison

headline: Freeze Warning issued October 17 at 7:41PM MDT until October 18 at 9:00AM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
description:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 23 expected.

* WHERE...Central Yampa River Basin, Upper Yampa River Basin, and
Animas River Basin.

* WHEN...From midnight tonight to 9 AM MDT Saturday.

* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other
sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor
plumbing.
areaDesc: Central Yampa River Basin; Upper Yampa River Basin; Animas River Basin

headline: Marine Weather Statement issued October 16 at 6:54AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
The Doppler radar indicated a line of strong thunderstorms,
capable of producing winds to around 30 knots and frequent
lightning. These thunderstorms were located over the Mona Passage,
moving east at 15 knots. These thunderstorms will move over the
western coastal waters of Puerto Rico and across the offshore
Caribbean waters through the morning hours.
areaDesc: Caribbean Waters of Puerto Rico from 10 NM to 17N, including the Coastal Waters of Saint Croix; Coastal Waters of Southern Puerto Rico out 10 NM; Mona Passage Southward to 17N; Coastal Waters OF Northwestern Puerto Rico out 10 NM; Coastal Waters OF Southwestern Puerto Rico out 10 NM

headline: Frost Advisory issued October 16 at 1:52PM EDT until October 17 at 9:00AM EDT by NWS Binghamton NY
description:
* WHAT...Temperatures falling into the low and mid 30s resulting in
frost formation.

* WHERE...Onondaga, Seneca, Southern Cayuga, and Yates Counties.

* WHEN...From midnight tonight to 9 AM EDT Friday.

* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive
outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.
areaDesc: Yates; Seneca; Southern Cayuga; Onondaga

* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 28 near Taos and as low

* WHERE...Estancia Valley, Upper Rio Grande Valley, Far Northeast

* WHEN...From late tonight through Friday morning.

* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other
sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor
plumbing.

headline: Gale Watch issued October 17 at 2:47PM CDT until October 19 at 10:00PM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
description:
* WHAT...Northwest gales to 35 kt and significant waves to 12 ft
occasionally to 16 ft possible. Highest waves east of Gary.

* WHERE...Illinois and Indiana nearshore from Winthrop Harbor IL
to Michigan City IN.

* WHEN...From Sunday morning through Sunday evening.

* IMPACTS...Strong winds can cause hazardous waves which could
capsize or damage vessels and reduce visibility.
areaDesc: Winthrop Harbor to Wilmette Harbor IL; Wilmette Harbor to Northerly Island IL; Northerly Island to Calumet Harbor IL; Calumet Harbor IL to Gary IN; Gary to Burns Harbor IN; Burns Harbor to Michigan City IN

headline: Frost Advisory issued October 16 at 1:18PM EDT until October 17 at 9:00AM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
description:
* WHAT...Temperatures between 32 to 36 degrees will result in frost
formation.

* WHERE...In New York, Eastern Clinton and Eastern Essex Counties.
In Vermont, Western Addison, Grand Isle, Western Chittenden, and
Western Franklin Counties.

* WHEN...From 10 PM this evening to 9 AM EDT Friday.

* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive
outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Northerly winds will reduce the likelihood of
frost in the vicinity of Lake Champlain.
areaDesc: Eastern Clinton; Eastern Essex; Grand Isle; Western Franklin; Western Chittenden; Western Addison

headline: Small Craft Advisory issued October 16 at 2:16PM PDT until October 18 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
description:

steep seas 4 to 6 increasing to 7 to 10 ft Friday night.

* WHERE...South of Port Orford Thursday through Friday evening,
then all areas.

* WHEN...From 11 AM Thursday to 8 PM PDT Saturday.

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds and/or steep seas could capsize or
damage smaller vessels.

* View the hazard area in detail at https://go.usa.gov/x6hks
areaDesc: Coastal waters from Cape Blanco OR to Pt. St. George CA out 10 nm; Waters from Cape Blanco OR to Pt. St. George CA from 10 to 60 nm

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 16 at 4:06PM MDT until October 16 at 4:45PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
At 406 PM MDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Stratton,
moving northeast at 35 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to
roofs, siding, and trees.

This severe storm will be near...
Stratton around 410 PM MDT.

This includes the following highways...
Interstate 70 in Colorado between mile markers 415 and 431.
Highway 385 between mile markers 197 and 206, and near mile marker
211.
areaDesc: Kit Carson, CO

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 6:04AM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD
description:
Patchy dense fog can be expected this morning. Motorists should
expect rapidly changing visibility, down to near zero at times.
Remember to use your low beam headlights in fog, slow down, and
provide plenty of braking distance between yourself and any
vehicles in front of you.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 9:36PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
At 935 PM AST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm
over central to eastern St. Croix, moving northeast at 15 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects.

Locations impacted include...
Grove Place, Frederiksted South, Frederiksted, and Christiansted.
areaDesc: St Croix

headline: Flood Warning issued October 16 at 9:13PM EDT until October 18 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South
Carolina...

Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Horry and
Marion Counties.

* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.

* WHERE...Little Pee Dee River at Galivants Ferry.

* WHEN...Until Saturday morning.

* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Flood waters will begin to affect
residential yards in the Fork Retch community upstream of
Galivants Ferry near the town of Nichols. Swampland flooding
becomes noticeable and natural boat landings will be flooded.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 9:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 9.2 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage
early tomorrow afternoon and continue falling to 6.7 feet
Tuesday evening.
- Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
- weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Horry, SC; Marion, SC

headline: Fire Weather Watch issued October 17 at 1:39PM MDT until October 19 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
description:
The National Weather Service in Denver has issued a Fire Weather
Watch for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect
Sunday afternoon.

* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 216, 239, 241, 246 and 247.

* TIMING...Sunday afternoon.

* WINDS...Southwest 10 to 15 mph with gusts 25 to 30 mph.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 2:48PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
description:
Light snow fell overnight and during the day Friday across many
parts of the Interior. Most accumulations were on the order of 1
to 3 inches. While most roadways have remained wet as opposed to
icy today, that could change overnight. Additional light snow is
expected later tonight and throughout the day Saturday. In
addition most areas will see temperatures drop into the upper 20's
to near 30 degrees overnight which could result in some icy
conditions for local roadways overnight tonight and early
Saturday.

headline: Flood Warning issued October 17 at 8:58AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...

St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.

.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to
recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The
river is forecast to remain steady or slowly fall within Moderate
Flood Stage through this weekend and into early next week. However,
tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.

For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is
forecast.

Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.

The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is
forecast.

* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes
on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the
parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of
Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue
Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake
Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest
to the river on McPherson Lane.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 8:30 AM EDT Friday the stage was 3.2 feet.
- Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 8:30 AM EDT Friday was 3.3 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood
stage at 3.2 feet today into early Saturday, falling slightly
to 3.1 feet this weekend.
- Flood stage is 2.3 feet.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 3:01PM PDT until October 18 at 12:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
description:
* WHAT...A moderate risk of sneaker waves.

* WHERE...All beaches of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.

* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday morning.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on
beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These
waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly
pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious
injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping
anyone caught underneath.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The risk of sneaker waves will peak
during Friday evening, but seas will continue to build through
Saturday morning. After brief improvement Saturday night,
hazardous conditions due to high surf are possible late Sunday
into early Monday.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 8:14PM EDT until October 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
description:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents and large breaking waves
expected in the surf zone.

* WHERE...The beaches north of Cape Hatteras.

* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT Saturday through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw
a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck
and back injuries.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 12:30 PM Saturday.

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 16 at 6:13PM MDT until October 16 at 6:45PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
SVRGLD

The National Weather Service in Goodland has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Southeastern Yuma County in northeastern Colorado...
Northwestern Cheyenne County in northwestern Kansas...

* Until 645 PM MDT/745 PM CDT/.

* At 612 PM MDT/712 PM CDT/, a severe thunderstorm was located 8
miles north of Bonny Reservoir, moving northeast at 45 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* This severe thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
southeastern Yuma County in northeastern Colorado and northwestern
Cheyenne Counties in northwestern Kansas, including the following
locations... Beecher Island.
areaDesc: Yuma, CO; Cheyenne, KS

headline: High Surf Advisory issued October 17 at 2:15PM PDT until October 20 at 11:00AM PDT by NWS Medford OR
description:
* WHAT...For the Beach Hazards Statement. A moderate risk of
sneaker waves. For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves
of 20-25 feet expected.

* WHERE...All beaches of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.

* WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through Saturday
morning. For the High Surf Advisory, from 11 AM Sunday to 11
AM PDT Monday.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on
beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These
waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly
pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious
injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping
anyone caught underneath. Large breaking waves will create
hazardous conditions along and within the surf zone, and could
inundate beaches and low lying shorelines. Beach erosion is
possible, and exposed infrastructure may be damaged.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The risk of sneaker waves will peak this
evening, but seas will continue to build through Saturday
morning and linger through the day Saturday. After brief
improvement Saturday night, hazardous conditions due to high
surf are expected late Sunday into early Monday with the highest
waves peaking out Sunday night.

* View the hazard area in detail at
https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 5:54AM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
description:
Fine fuels remain very dry across Vermont according to the
Vermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation. This,
combined with gusty northerly winds of 25 to 30 MPH and relative
humidity as low as 35%, may have an impact on fire weather
conditions. If any fires were to start the weather and fuel
conditions could cause fires to quickly get out of control and be
difficult to contain.

For more information about the current fire danger rating, any burn
restrictions, and wildfire prevention and education, please visit
your state forestry or environmental protection website. Remember, a
debris burn ban is in effect for all of Vermont which means no
open burning of debris is allowed.
areaDesc: Western Chittenden; Western Addison; Orange; Western Rutland; Eastern Addison; Eastern Rutland; Western Windsor; Eastern Windsor

headline: Flash Flood Warning issued October 16 at 8:24PM CDT until October 16 at 11:30PM CDT by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
description:
FFWMAF

The National Weather Service in Midland/Odessa has issued a

* Flash Flood Warning for...
Northwestern Reeves County in southwestern Texas...

* Until 1130 PM CDT.

* At 824 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing
heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1.5 and 2 inches of
rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are
possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected
to begin shortly.

HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.

SOURCE...Radar.

IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban
areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as
other poor drainage and low-lying areas.

* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...
mainly rural areas of Northwestern Reeves County

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 2:13AM PDT until October 18 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
description:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.

* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South
Washington Coast.

* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach
than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves
can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull
them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or
drowning.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when
sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions
in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the
water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially
watchful of children.

headline: Coastal Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 3:20AM EDT until October 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
description:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, up to 1 to 2 feet of
inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines
and tidal waterways. For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous
rip currents and large breaking waves in the surf zone.

* WHERE...Hatteras Island.

* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 8 PM EDT Friday.
For the Beach Hazards Statement, through this evening.

* IMPACTS...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is
possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways
resulting in a low threat of property damage. Some roads and low
lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes
adjacent to the waterfront will experience shallow flooding.
Portions of NC-12 may be impacted with ocean overwash around
high tide. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a
swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and
back injuries.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 10:30 am this morning.
areaDesc: Hatteras Island

high tide. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a
swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and
back injuries.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 10:30 am this morning.

headline: Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 3:15PM CDT until October 16 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Goodland KS

rainfall is expected.

* WHERE...Portions of northwest Kansas, including the following
county, Rawlins and southwest Nebraska, including the following
counties, Hitchcock and Red Willow.

* WHEN...Until 700 PM CDT.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.

thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream
flooding. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen.

flooding.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 6:42AM PDT by NWS Elko NV
description:
Patchy fog will continue across portions of northern Nevada,
specifically Humboldt, northern Lander/Eureka, and Elko counties
this morning. Satellite imagery and remote sensing platforms show
patchy fog in various locations across Interstate 80, US Highway
93 and 95, and various State Routes in these areas with
reductions to visibility of one mile or less in spots. Motorists
are urged to use caution when driving along these and other
roadways as rapid changes to visibility are likely this morning.
Please use low beams and reduce speeds to arrive safely to your
destination.

Visit www.weather.gov/elko for the latest weather information.
areaDesc: Humboldt County; Northern Lander County and Northern Eureka County

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 2:49PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
description:
A couple waves of energy will bring the potential for snow squalls
Saturday through Sunday night. Squalls are notoriously quick in
nature, but can bring brief heavy bursts of snow and wind gusts up
to 35 mph which can reduce visibility below 1 mile at times. Snow
accumulations of 1 to 3 inches is possible, with the heaviest
expected in the Western Seward Peninsula and most of it coming
Saturday night through Sunday.
areaDesc: Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; St Lawrence Island

Atlantic Waters of Puerto Rico AND USVI from 10 NM to 19.5N...

At 706 PM AST, Doppler radar indicated a strong thunderstorm, capable
of producing winds to around 30 knots. This thunderstorm was located
over the northern offshore Atlantic waters, moving northeast at 15
to 20 knots. A line of strong thunderstorms is also just outside the
local offshore Atlantic waters, north of 19.5N, moving southeast at
around 15 to 20 knots and capable of producing winds to around 30
knots.

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 3:22AM PDT until October 18 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
description:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an
increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.

* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes
National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern
Monterey Bay and Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast
Counties.

* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly
farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and
jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger
in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should
always swim near a lifeguard.
areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

headline: Flood Warning issued October 17 at 10:13AM EDT until October 18 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South
Carolina...

Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Horry and
Marion Counties.

* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.

* WHERE...Little Pee Dee River at Galivants Ferry.

* WHEN...Until tomorrow morning.

* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Flood waters will begin to affect
residential yards in the Fork Retch community upstream of
Galivants Ferry near the town of Nichols. Swampland flooding
becomes noticeable and natural boat landings will be flooded.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 10:00 AM EDT Friday the stage was 9.1 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage
this afternoon and continue falling to 6.1 feet Wednesday
morning.
- Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
- weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Horry, SC; Marion, SC

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 16 at 7:10PM CDT until October 16 at 7:45PM CDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
At 709 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 7 miles north of
Bird City, or 13 miles northeast of St. Francis, moving northeast at
30 mph.

HAZARD...Ping pong ball size hail and 60 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Public report of 1 inch hail in Wheeler.

IMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail
damage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect wind
damage to roofs, siding, and trees.

Locations impacted include...
Bird City.
areaDesc: Cheyenne, KS

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 12:55AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
description:
Patchy dense fog is currently developing over the North-central
plains east of the highway 89 corridor. Anyone traveling tonight
may encounter highly variable visibility across short distances,
falling to as low as a half mile or less. Frost deposition may
cause some roads to become slippery, particularly over bridges
and overpasses. Slow down and allow extra time to reach your
destination if traveling tonight into Thursday morning.

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 16 at 6:52PM CDT until October 16 at 7:45PM CDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
At 651 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 4 miles east of St.
Francis, moving northeast at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Two inch hail and 70 mph wind gusts.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail
damage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect
considerable tree damage. Wind damage is also likely to
mobile homes, roofs, and outbuildings.

Locations impacted include...
St. Francis, Bird City, and Wheeler.
areaDesc: Cheyenne, KS

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 8:43PM CDT by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
description:
At 842 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 9
miles southeast of Orla, or 11 miles west of Mentone, moving east at
20 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects.

Locations impacted include...
Mentone.
areaDesc: Loving; Reeves County Plains

headline: Tornado Warning issued October 16 at 4:50PM MDT until October 16 at 5:15PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
At 450 PM MDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 10 miles north of Burlington, moving northeast at 40 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
northeastern Kit Carson County.

This includes Highway 385 between mile markers 196 and 206, and near
mile marker 211.
areaDesc: Kit Carson, CO

headline: Coastal Flood Statement issued October 17 at 4:02PM EDT until October 18 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Key West FL
description:
* WHAT...Minor saltwater flooding.

* WHERE...Florida Keys.

* WHEN...Through early Saturday morning.

* IMPACTS...Minor saltwater flooding of low elevation streets and
lots is likely. Some storm drains will overflow, and some
seawalls and docks will be overtopped. Boaters can expect less
clearance under fixed bridges. Motorists should remember that
persistent puddles around the times of high tide are almost
certain to contain a mix of saltwater. In the Upper Keys, there
will be little relief in minor salt water flooding, even at
around the times of high tide.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
areaDesc: Monroe Upper Keys; Monroe Middle Keys; Monroe Lower Keys

headline: Special Marine Warning issued October 17 at 8:07AM AST until October 17 at 9:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
SMWSJU

The National Weather Service in San Juan has issued a

* Special Marine Warning for...
Anegada Passage east of Virgin Gorda and Saint Croix south to
17N...
Caribbean Waters of Puerto Rico from 10 NM to 17N, including the
Coastal Waters of Saint Croix...

* Until 900 AM AST.

* At 803 AM AST, a cluster of severe thunderstorms capable of
producing waterspouts was located off to the south to southwest
at around 20 miles of St Croix, moving east at 5 to 15 knots.

HAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts to 40 knots.

SOURCE...Radar.

IMPACT...Waterspouts can easily overturn boats and create locally
hazardous seas. Small craft could be damaged in briefly
higher winds and suddenly higher waves.
areaDesc: Anegada Passage east of Virgin Gorda and Saint Croix south to 17N; Caribbean Waters of Puerto Rico from 10 NM to 17N, including the Coastal Waters of Saint Croix

headline: Flood Warning issued October 16 at 3:46PM EDT until October 18 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South
Carolina...

Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Horry and
Marion Counties.

* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.

* WHERE...Little Pee Dee River at Galivants Ferry.

* WHEN...Until Saturday morning.

* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Flood waters will begin to affect
residential yards in the Fork Retch community upstream of
Galivants Ferry near the town of Nichols. Swampland flooding
becomes noticeable and natural boat landings will be flooded.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 3:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 9.1 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage
early tomorrow afternoon and continue falling to 7.3 feet
Tuesday morning.
- Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
- weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Horry, SC; Marion, SC

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 4:52AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
description:
A couple waves of energy will bring the potential for snow squalls
Saturday through Sunday night. Squalls are notoriously quick in
nature, but can bring brief heavy bursts of snow and wind gusts up
to 35 mph which can reduce visibility below 1 mile at times. Snow
accumulations of 1 to 3 inches is possible, with the heaviest
expected in the Western Seward Peninsula and most of it coming
Saturday night through Sunday.
areaDesc: Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; St Lawrence Island

headline: Flood Advisory issued October 17 at 5:17AM HST until October 17 at 7:15AM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.

* WHERE...The island of Kauai in Kauai County.

* WHEN...Until 715 AM HST.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding on roads, poor drainage areas, and in
streams.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 515 AM HST, radar indicated bands of heavy rain and
thunderstorms continue to move over the entire island of
Kauai. Rain continues to fall at a rate of 1 to 2 inches per
hour.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
the entire island of Kauai.
areaDesc: Kauai, HI

headline: Special Marine Warning issued October 16 at 7:57PM AST until October 16 at 8:45PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
SMWSJU

The National Weather Service in San Juan has issued a

* Special Marine Warning for...
Caribbean Waters of Puerto Rico from 10 NM to 17N, including the
Coastal Waters of Saint Croix...

* Until 845 PM AST.

* At 755 PM AST, severe thunderstorms capable of producing
waterspouts was located over mainly areas of Caribbean Waters,
moving northeast at 20 knots.

HAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts 34 knots or greater.

SOURCE...Radar.

IMPACT...Waterspouts can easily overturn boats and create locally
hazardous seas. Small craft could be damaged in briefly
higher winds and suddenly higher waves.

* The severe thunderstorms will remain over mainly open waters.
areaDesc: Caribbean Waters of Puerto Rico from 10 NM to 17N, including the Coastal Waters of Saint Croix

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 5:51PM EDT until October 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
description:
* WHAT...For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents,
large breaking waves, and strong longshore currents in the surf
zone. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, up to 1 to 2 feet of
inundation above ground level in low- lying areas near
shorelines and tidal waterways.

* WHERE...Hatteras Island.

* WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through Friday
evening. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 8 PM EDT Friday.

* IMPACTS...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is
possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways
resulting in a low threat of property damage. Some roads and low
lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes
adjacent to the waterfront will experience shallow flooding.
Portions of NC-12 may be impacted with ocean overwash around
high tide. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a
swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and
back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous
swimming conditions.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 11:30 AM Friday.
areaDesc: Hatteras Island

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 2:16PM PDT until October 18 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
description:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an
increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.

* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes
National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern
Monterey Bay and Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast
Counties.

* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly
farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and
jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger
in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should
always swim near a lifeguard.
areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

headline: Coastal Flood Statement issued October 16 at 2:04AM EDT until October 17 at 12:00AM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
description:
* WHAT...Up to one half foot of inundation above ground level
expected in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal
waterways (3.0 to 5.0 feet Mean Lower Low Water).

* WHERE...Dukes MA and Nantucket MA Counties.

* WHEN...This evening.

* IMPACTS...Roads remain passable. Low lying areas and roads
near Nantucket Harbor, including Easy Street, may experience
pockets of shallow flooding less than one foot deep.
areaDesc: Dukes; Nantucket

headline: Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 1:50AM MDT until October 16 at 3:15AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
description:
* WHAT...Arroyo and small stream flooding caused by excessive
rainfall continues.

* WHERE...A portion of north central New Mexico, including the
following counties, Los Alamos, south central Rio Arriba and
northwestern Santa Fe.

* WHEN...Until 315 AM MDT.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
Water over roadways. Overflowing poor drainage areas.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 149 AM MDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to
training thunderstorms. This will cause arroyo and small
stream flooding. Between 1 and 1.5 inches of rain have
fallen.
- Additional rainfall amounts of 0.25 to 0.5 inches are
expected over the area. This additional rain will result in
minor flooding.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Los Alamos, Espanola, White Rock, Santa Clara Pueblo,

headline: Tornado Warning issued October 16 at 4:40PM MDT until October 16 at 5:15PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
TORGLD

The National Weather Service in Goodland has issued a

* Tornado Warning for...
Northeastern Kit Carson County in east central Colorado...

* Until 515 PM MDT.

* At 439 PM MDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 5 miles north of Bethune, or 8 miles northwest of
Burlington, moving northeast at 35 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
northeastern Kit Carson County.

This includes Highway 385 between mile markers 195 and 206, and near
mile marker 211.

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 2:10PM PDT until October 18 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
description:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.

* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South
Washington Coast.

* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach
than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves
can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull
them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or
drowning.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when
sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions
in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the
water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially
watchful of children.
areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 3:40AM PDT by NWS Elko NV
description:
Patchy fog will continue across portions of Humboldt and northern
Lander/Eureka counties this morning. Satellite imagery and remote
sensing platforms show patchy fog with visibility dropping to one
mile or less in spots. Locations and roads being affected are US
Highway 95 from Winnemucca north to Paradise Valley, I-80 from the
Humboldt/Pershing county line east to Battle Mountain, and Jungo
road from Antelope Summit to Winnemucca. Motorists are urged to
use caution when driving along these and other roadways as rapid
changes to visibility are likely this morning.

Visit www.weather.gov/elko for the latest weather information.
areaDesc: Humboldt County; Northern Lander County and Northern Eureka County

headline: Flood Warning issued October 16 at 9:48AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...

St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.

.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to
recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The
river is forecast to remain steady or slowly fall within Moderate
Flood Stage through this weekend and into early next week. However,
tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.

For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is
forecast.

Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.

The next statement will be issued this evening at 1100 PM EDT.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is
forecast.

* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes
on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the
parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of
Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue
Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake
Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest
to the river on McPherson Lane.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 8:30 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 3.3 feet.
- Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 8:30 AM EDT Thursday was 3.3 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood
stage at 3.2 feet through late week, falling to 3.1 feet this
weekend.
- Flood stage is 2.3 feet.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

headline: Flood Warning issued October 16 at 8:55PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...

St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.

.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to
recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The
river is forecast to remain steady or slowly fall within Moderate
Flood Stage through this weekend and into early next week. However,
tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.

For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is
forecast.

Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.

The next statement will be issued Friday afternoon at noon EDT.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is
forecast.

* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes
on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the
parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of
Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue
Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake
Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest
to the river on McPherson Lane.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 8:30 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 3.2 feet.
- Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 8:30 PM EDT Thursday was 3.3 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood
stage at 3.2 feet.
- Flood stage is 2.3 feet.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

headline: Flood Warning issued October 17 at 8:54PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
description:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...

St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.

.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to
recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The
river is forecast to remain steady or slowly fall within Moderate
Flood Stage through this weekend and into early next week. However,
tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.

For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is
forecast.

Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.

The next statement will be issued Saturday morning at 1100 AM EDT.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is
forecast.

* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.

* WHEN...Until further notice.

* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes
on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the
parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of
Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue
Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake
Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest
to the river on McPherson Lane.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 8:30 PM EDT Friday the stage was 3.2 feet.
- Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet.
- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours
ending at 8:30 PM EDT Friday was 3.3 feet.
- Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood
stage at 3.2 feet.
- Flood stage is 2.3 feet.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 2:04PM CDT by NWS Corpus Christi TX
description:

will make the atmosphere favorable for the development of weak
tropical funnels today. Most of these funnel clouds will be
short lived and usually do not touch the ground. However, you
should be prepared to seek shelter in the event a funnel does
reach the ground.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 11:02AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
description:
A pair of light disturbances will impact the Interior, bringing
light snowfall throughout the evening tonight through the weekend.
Accumulations of 1-3 inches of snow are expected through this
weekend with higher amounts in higher elevations and areas near
Healy.

Due to the colder temperatures setting in, this could bring our
first permanent snowpack for some areas. Snowfall is expected to
accumulate on roadways, making travel conditions difficult at
times.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 8:43AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
description:
Light rain and snow is falling across portions of Southwest MT
this morning, including areas around Bozeman, Bozeman Pass on
Interstate 90, Big Sky, West Yellowstone, Norris Hill on Highway
287 and Raynolds Pass on Highway 87.

Rain and snow levels vary across Southwest MT at 830 AM, from
about 5500 feet to about 6500 feet. Some higher elevation
roadways, such as Raynolds Pass, Big Sky and the Bridger area do
have some snow and slush accumulation on roadways.

Expect the light precipitation to continue through late this
morning, before beginning to diminish.

Those traveling across Southwest MT should be alert for quickly
changing road conditions and areas of poor driving visibility.
areaDesc: Big Belt, Bridger and Castle Mountains; Madison River Valley; Gallatin Valley; Gallatin and Madison County Mountains and Centennial Mountains

The National Weather Service in Midland/Odessa has issued a

East Central Jeff Davis County in southwestern Texas...

inches of rain are estimated to have fallen in the past hour.

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 12:51AM PDT by NWS Elko NV
description:
Patchy fog has developed across portions of Humboldt and northern
Lander/Eureka counties this morning. Satellite imagery and remote
sensing platforms are depicting patchy fog with visibility
dropping to one mile or less in spots. Locations and roads being
affected are US Highway 95 from Winnemucca north to Paradise
Valley, I-80 from the Humboldt/Pershing county line east to Battle
Mountain, and Jungo road from Antelope Summit to Winnemucca.
Motorists are urged to use caution when driving along these and
other roadways as rapid changes to visibility are likely this
morning.

Visit www.weather.gov/elko for the latest weather information.

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 16 at 6:35PM CDT until October 16 at 7:15PM CDT by NWS North Platte NE
description:
SVRLBF

The National Weather Service in North Platte has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Southeastern Perkins County in southwestern Nebraska...
Northeastern Chase County in southwestern Nebraska...
Southwestern Lincoln County in southwestern Nebraska...
Northwestern Hayes County in southwestern Nebraska...

* Until 715 PM CDT/615 PM MDT/.

* At 635 PM CDT/535 PM MDT/, a severe thunderstorm was located 9
miles south of Elsie, or 19 miles northeast of Imperial, moving
northeast at 45 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* Locations impacted include...
Wallace, Dickens, and Grainton.

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 4:11AM PDT until October 18 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
description:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.

* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South
Washington Coast.

* WHEN...For the first Beach Hazards Statement, from noon PDT
today through this afternoon. For the second Beach Hazards
Statement, from Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach
than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves
can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull
them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or
drowning.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when
sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in
the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water.
Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of
children and pets.
areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 8:49PM CDT by NWS Topeka KS
description:
At 849 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near
Osage City, moving northeast at 45 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and half inch hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down small tree limbs and blow
around unsecured objects. Minor damage to vegetation is
possible.

Locations impacted include...
Osage City, Carbondale, Overbrook, Lyndon, Burlingame, Scranton, and
Pomona Lake.
areaDesc: Osage

headline: Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 2:05AM AST until October 16 at 5:15AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive
rainfall is expected.

* WHERE...Aguada, Aguadilla, Moca and Rincon.

* WHEN...Until 515 AM AST.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
Water over roadways.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 204 AM AST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to
thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream
flooding. Up to 1.5 inches of rain have fallen.
- Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are expected
over the area. This additional rain will result in minor
flooding.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
areaDesc: Aguada, PR; Aguadilla, PR; Moca, PR; Rincon, PR

including the Dry Tortugas, and Florida Bay.

* WHEN...In Effect.

* IMPACTS...A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 20
to 33 knots, or seas of 7 feet or greater, are expected to
produce hazardous conditions for small craft. These hazardous

falls on slippery decks, rub damage along docks and seawalls,
swamped bows at reef tract mooring balls, and dragging anchors.

seawalls and docks will be overtopped. In the Lower and Middle

even outside the windows of high tide. Boaters can expect less

certain to contain a mix of saltwater.

These severe thunderstorms will remain over mainly rural areas of
northeastern Kit Carson County.

Interstate 70 in Colorado between mile markers 416 and 431.
Highway 385 between mile markers 197 and 206, and near mile marker
211.

headline: Marine Weather Statement issued October 17 at 1:50PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
At 146 PM AST, Doppler radar indicated strong thunderstorms,
capable of producing winds to around 30 knots. These
thunderstorms were located over mainly areas of the Caribbean, Mona
Passage and the nearshore northern waters, moving northeast at 15
to 20 knots. Development of additional t-storms over the waters
is expected along with movement of current t-storms over the
offshore Atlantic Waters.
areaDesc: Atlantic Waters of Puerto Rico AND USVI from 10 NM to 19.5N; Coastal Waters of Northern Puerto Rico out 10 NM; Caribbean Waters of Puerto Rico from 10 NM to 17N, including the Coastal Waters of Saint Croix; Coastal Waters of Southern Puerto Rico out 10 NM; Mona Passage Southward to 17N; Coastal Waters OF Northwestern Puerto Rico out 10 NM; Coastal Waters OF Southwestern Puerto Rico out 10 NM

headline: Special Marine Warning issued October 16 at 4:37PM CDT until October 16 at 5:00PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
description:
SMWHGX

The National Weather Service in League City has issued a

* Special Marine Warning for...
Coastal waters from High Island to Freeport TX out 20 NM...
Galveston Bay...

* Until 500 PM CDT.

* At 436 PM CDT, a shower producing waterspouts was located near
Offatts Bayou, or 7 nm south of Galveston Pier 21, moving northwest
at 5 knots.

HAZARD...Waterspouts.

SOURCE...Emergency management.

IMPACT...Waterspouts can create locally hazardous seas.

* Locations impacted include...
Galveston Causeway, Offatts Bayou, Galveston Ship Channel, and
northeastern West Bay.
areaDesc: Galveston Bay; Coastal waters from High Island to Freeport TX out 20 NM

county, Red Willow.

thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream
flooding. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen.

McCook.

headline: Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 2:44AM AST until October 16 at 5:15AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive
rainfall is expected.

* WHERE...Anasco and Mayaguez.

* WHEN...Until 515 AM AST.

* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
Water over roadways.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 244 AM AST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to
thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream
flooding. Up to 1.5 inches of rain have fallen.
- Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are expected
over the area. This additional rain will result in minor
flooding.

headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued October 16 at 3:52PM MDT until October 16 at 4:45PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
description:
SVRGLD

The National Weather Service in Goodland has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Central Kit Carson County in east central Colorado...

* Until 445 PM MDT.

* At 350 PM MDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 10 miles south of
Stratton, moving northeast at 40 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage
to roofs, siding, and trees.

* This severe thunderstorm will be near...
Stratton around 405 PM MDT.

Interstate 70 in Colorado between mile markers 415 and 431.
Highway 385 between mile markers 197 and 206, and near mile marker
211.

headline: The Beach Hazards Statement has been cancelled.
description: The Beach Hazards Statement has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.
areaDesc: Hatteras Island

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 16 at 3:47AM EDT until October 16 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
description:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, up to 1 to 2 feet of
inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines
and tidal waterways. For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous
rip currents, large breaking waves expected, and strong
longshore currents in the surf zone.

* WHERE...Hatteras Island.

* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 8 PM EDT Friday.
For the Beach Hazards Statement, from 8 AM EDT this morning
through this evening.

* IMPACTS...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is
possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways
resulting in a low threat of property damage. Some roads and low
lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes
adjacent to the waterfront will experience shallow flooding.
Portions of NC-12 may be impacted with ocean overwash around
high tide. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away
from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a
swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and
back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous
swimming conditions.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip
currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide,
which will occur around 10:30 AM Thursday.
areaDesc: Hatteras Island

headline: Special Marine Warning issued October 16 at 9:19PM AST until October 16 at 10:15PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
description:
SMWSJU

The National Weather Service in San Juan has issued a

* Special Marine Warning for...
Atlantic Waters of Puerto Rico AND USVI from 10 NM to 19.5N...

* Until 1015 PM AST.

* At 917 PM AST, a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing
waterspouts was located over mainly areas of offshore Atlantic
Waters, moving southeast at 15 knots.

HAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts to 40 knots.

SOURCE...Radar.

IMPACT...Waterspouts can easily overturn boats and create locally
hazardous seas. Small craft could be damaged in briefly
higher winds and suddenly higher waves.

* The severe thunderstorm will remain over mainly open waters.
areaDesc: Atlantic Waters of Puerto Rico AND USVI from 10 NM to 19.5N

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 4:43AM PDT until October 18 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
description:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an
increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.

* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes
National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern
Monterey Bay and Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast
Counties.

* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday evening.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly
farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and
jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger
in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should
always swim near a lifeguard.
areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast

Southwestern Humboldt and Mendocino Coast Counties.

* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday evening. .

* IMPACTS...Large, unexpected waves can sweep across the beach
without warning, sweeping people into the sea from rocks,
jetties, and beaches. These sneaker waves can also move large
objects such as logs, crushing anyone caught underneath.

* WHEN...Until 3 PM PDT Saturday.

* IMPACTS...Conditions will be hazardous to small craft.

description: The Beach Hazards Statement has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 1:59PM PDT until October 19 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
description:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.

* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South
Washington Coast.

* WHEN...For the first Beach Hazards Statement, from this
afternoon through Saturday evening. For the second Beach
Hazards Statement, from Sunday afternoon through Sunday evening.

* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach
than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves
can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull
them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or
drowning.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when
sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in
the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water.
Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of
children and pets.
areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 7:40PM CDT by NWS North Platte NE
description:
At 740 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along
a line extending from near Gandy to near North Platte Airport to near
Lake Maloney State Recreation Area. Movement was east at 55 mph.

HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and penny size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around
unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is
possible.

Locations impacted include...
Brady, Maxwell, North Platte Airport, Keith, Cottonwood Canyon State
Wildlife Management Area, Etna, Milldale, Finchville, and Vroman.

This includes the following highways...
Interstate 80 in Nebraska between mile markers 180 and 206.
Highway 83 between mile markers 91 and 105.
